natural problem:
The sum of two odd functions is always odd, even, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither".
natural solution: Let $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ be odd functions, so $f(-x) = -f(x)$ and $g(-x) = -g(x).$  Let $h(x) = f(x) + g(x).$  Then \[h(-x) = f(-x) + g(-x) = -f(x) - g(x) = -h(x),\]so $h(x)$ is $\boxed{\text{odd}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f (-x) = - f x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g (-x) = - g x"
shows  "\<forall> x. (f x + g x) = - (f (-x) + g (-x))"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sum of two odd functions is always odd, even, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{odd}
 ### Proof
 Let $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ be odd functions, so $f(-x) = -f(x)$ and $g(-x) = -g(x).$  Let $h(x) = f(x) + g(x).$  Then \[h(-x) = f(-x) + g(-x) = -f(x) - g(x) = -h(x),\]so $h(x)$ is $\boxed{\text{odd}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f (-x) = - f x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g (-x) = - g x"
shows  "\<forall> x. (f x + g x) = - (f (-x) + g (-x))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For all real numbers $x$, if $f$ and $g$ are functions such that $f(-x) = -f(x)$ and $g(-x) = -g(x)$, prove that $f(x) + g(x) = - (f(-x) + g(-x))$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "odd f"
and h1 : "odd g"
shows  "odd (\<lambda>x. f x + g x)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sum of two odd functions is always odd, even, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{odd}
 ### Proof
 Let $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ be odd functions, so $f(-x) = -f(x)$ and $g(-x) = -g(x).$  Let $h(x) = f(x) + g(x).$  Then \[h(-x) = f(-x) + g(-x) = -f(x) - g(x) = -h(x),\]so $h(x)$ is $\boxed{\text{odd}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "odd f"
and h1 : "odd g"
shows  "odd (\<lambda>x. f x + g x)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given two odd functions $f$ and $g$, prove that the function defined by the sum of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ is also an odd function.

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f (-x) = - f x"

shows  "\<forall> x. (f x + g x) = - (f (-x) + g (-x))"
a_8.formal solution:

 The sum of two odd functions is always odd, even, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{odd}
 ### Proof
 Let $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ be odd functions, so $f(-x) = -f(x)$ and $g(-x) = -g(x).$  Let $h(x) = f(x) + g(x).$  Then \[h(-x) = f(-x) + g(-x) = -f(x) - g(x) = -h(x),\]so $h(x)$ is $\boxed{\text{odd}}.$

fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"

shows  "\<forall> x. (f x + g x) = - (f (-x) + g (-x))"

a_8.informal problem: If two functions f(x) and g(x) both satisfy the property that the function of a negative x equals the negative of the function of x, show that for all x, the sum of the functions f(x) and g(x) is equal to the negative of the sum of the functions f(-x) and g(-x).

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f (- x) = - f x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g (- x) = - g x"
shows  "\<forall> x. (f + g) (- x) = - (f + g) x"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The sum of two odd functions is always odd, even, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{odd}
 ### Proof
 Let $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ be odd functions, so $f(-x) = -f(x)$ and $g(-x) = -g(x).$  Let $h(x) = f(x) + g(x).$  Then \[h(-x) = f(-x) + g(-x) = -f(x) - g(x) = -h(x),\]so $h(x)$ is $\boxed{\text{odd}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f (- x) = - f x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g (- x) = - g x"
shows  "\<forall> x. (f + g) (- x) = - (f + g) x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given two functions $f$ and $g$ such that $f(-x) = -f(x)$ and $g(-x) = -g(x)$ for all real numbers $x$, prove that for all real numbers $x$, $(f + g)(-x) = -(f + g)(x)$.
